Lawyer: Swartz rejected MIT plea deal

Prosecutors told Aaron Swartz that he would have to agree to a guilty plea and six months in prison to settle his case short of trial, his attorney said. (Boston Globe)

Boston again has lowest number of fire fatalities among large cities in the US

For the second year in a row, Boston had the lowest number of fire deaths for large cities, recording one fatality in 2012, fire officials said today. (Boston Globe)

Opinion | Dan Shaughnessy

Patriots-Texans was a laugher from start to finish

The Patriots took care of the Texans, 41-28, in the first de facto preseason playoff game in NFL history to move on to the AFC Championship game.
Opinion | Christopher L. Gasper

Real playoffs start next week

The Patriots will need a better effort than they had against the Texans to beat a Ravens team that is Super Bowl contender varsity.

Lower-income areas hit hard by flu

The illness appears to be exacting a heavy toll on three neighborhoods — Dorchester, Roxbury, and Mattapan.
Opinion | Juliette Kayyem

Chuck Hagel will too set policy

The secretary of defense, Hagel’s defenders assert, does not set foreign policy. But have we learned nothing? Of course he does.

MIT investigating role in Swartz case

MIT will launch a “thorough analysis” of the school’s involvement in the federal hacking case against Aaron Swartz, who committed suicide Friday.
Opinion | Jennifer Graham

A generation gap at City Hall

Young mayors are doing great things, but the mayor-for-life set isn’t giving up so easily.

Deeper dives await the new Alvin

An overhaul of the storied Woods Hole-based sub Alvin will let scientists descend four miles below sea level to explore the earth’s final frontier.
